name: Kepler-126
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-126 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-126 is a star with 1.774999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.36 times its radius. It is located 779.61 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-126 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-126 b

Kepler-126 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.50 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-126.

The mass of Kepler-126 b is 2.65 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-126 b is 1.52 that of Earth. At 2.65 Earth masses, Kepler-126 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-126 c

Kepler-126 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 21.87 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-126.

The mass of Kepler-126 c is 2.89 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-126 c is 1.58 that of Earth. At 2.89 Earth masses, Kepler-126 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-126 d

Kepler-126 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.45 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 100.28 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-126.

The mass of Kepler-126 d is 8.67 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-126 d is 2.5 that of Earth. At 8.67 Earth masses, Kepler-126 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-126, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
